questions.text: A community survey revealed a high incidence of thalassemia, leading to the initiation of a screening program using the NESTROFT test. What would be the expected appearance of the NESTROFT test for a negative result?

options.label: A
options.text: Clear fluid with no visible lines in either tube.

options.label: B
options.text: Black lines visible in both the test and control tubes.

options.label: C
options.text: Black line visible in the control tube only.

options.label: D
options.text: Black line visible in the test tube only.

questions.correct_answer: B. Black lines visible in both the test and control tubes.
questions.explanation:
Test Result

Observation

Interpretation

Negative

Distinct black lines visible in both the test and control tubes.

Indicates no unlysed RBCs present. Thalassemia is not detected; osmotic stability is normal.


 

Positive

Black lines not visible in the test tube, but visible in the control tube.



 

Suggests the presence of unlysed RBCs, indicating osmotic fragility. May imply thalassemia or other conditions affecting RBC stability.

questions.text: An X-ray of the skull shows the characteristic findings described below. Which of the following diseases is most likely indicated by these findings?
questions.explanation:
Disease

X-ray Skull Finding

Thalassemia

(Option A)

"Hair-on-end" appearance due to increased erythropoiesis and skull remodelling.


 

Multiple Myeloma

(Option B)

"Punched-out" lytic lesions in the skull, indicative of bone erosion caused by myeloma cells.

 

 

Paget's Disease

(Option C)

Thickened skull bones with a "cotton wool" appearance due to disorganized bone remodelling.

Histiocytosis X

(Option D)

Lytic bone lesions with a "punched-out" appearance, especially in the skull, due to aggressive bone involvement.

questions.text: A newborn is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit due to respiratory distress and severe jaundice. The infant is lethargic and has poor feeding. Physical examination reveals pallor, marked hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized oedema. Laboratory tests indicate a haemoglobin level of 6 g/dL, elevated indirect bilirubin, and a reticulocyte count of 12%. What is the most likely underlying genetic cause of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Deletion of all four α-globin genes

questions.correct_answer: B. Deletion of all four α-globin genes
questions.explanation:
Hb Bart Hydrops Fetalis Syndrome

The most severe form of α-thalassemia, caused by the absence of all four α-globin genes (homozygous α0-thalassemia).

Common in Southeast Asia: High frequency due to the prevalence of α0-thalassemia.

Pathophysiology
  • Fetuses with α0-thalassemia mainly produce Hb Bart (γ4), which is ineffective for oxygen transport.
  • Small amounts of embryonic haemoglobins (Hbs Portland 1 and 2) allow survival until late pregnancy.

Clinical Course
  • Characterized by severe anaemia (Hb 3-8 g/dL), hepatosplenomegaly, generalized oedema, heart failure, and extramedullary erythropoiesis.
  • Associated congenital abnormalities include skeletal, cardiovascular, and urogenital defects.

Pregnancy Complications
  • Maternal: Preeclampsia, polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios, antepartum haemorrhage.
  • Postpartum: Retained placenta, eclampsia, haemorrhage, anaemia, sepsis.

Management
  • Intrauterine erythrocyte transfusions and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation have uncertain benefits due to developmental risks.
  • Early termination of at-risk pregnancies is advised due to severe complications.
  • Universal prenatal screening programs have been implemented to detect homozygous α-thalassemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with fatigue and intermittent jaundice. His blood film shows spherocytes, and his parents report a family history of similar symptoms. Laboratory tests reveal elevated indirect bilirubin and reticulocytosis. What is the most common underlying defect in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)
  • An inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red blood cell membrane skeleton, leading to spheroid, less deformable red cells vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.
  • 75% of cases are autosomal dominant.
  • Remaining cases often involve severe forms due to compound heterozygosity (inheritance of two different defects).

Etiopathogenesis

Spherocytosis Etiopathogenesis" data-author="" data-hash="10398" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/mEFsMIbiKrxPlmLOsDtR1744717931.png" />

 
  • HS is marked by a loss of membrane surface area relative to the intracellular volume, leading to spherical red blood cells with reduced or absent central pallor.
  • Spherocytes have decreased deformability, resulting in their retention and destruction in the spleen, causing hemolysis.
  • spectrin, ankyrin, AE1(band 3), protein 4.2 that weakens the vertical connections between the cytoskeletal framework and lipid bilayer.
  • The ANK1 gene on chromosome 8p produces Ankyrin.
  • Two proposed mechanisms for membrane loss:
    • In cells with spectrin/ankyrin deficiency.
    • Reduced AE1/protein.

Clinical features
  • 60-70% of patients present with moderate disease, typically in infancy or childhood.
  • Common findings in children include:
    • Anaemia may be asymptomatic,
    • Jaundice is usually intermittent and acholuric (unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia).
    • >75% show palpable splenomegaly.
    • Family history.

Complications
  • Gallbladder Disease: Chronic hemolysis can lead to bilirubinate gallstones.
  • Crisis Events:
    • Hemolytic Crisis: Commonly associated with viral illnesses in childhood; typically mild and self-resolving.
    • Aplastic Crisis: Rare but may cause severe anaemia and require hospitalization, often linked to parvovirus infection. Typically lasts 10–14 days and may reveal undiagnosed HS in asymptomatic patients.
    • Megaloblastic Crisis: Occurs in patients with increased folate needs, preventable by supplementation.
  • Other rare complications may include leg ulcers, chronic dermatitis, and skeletal abnormalities.
  • HS has been associated with increased risks of hematologic malignancies and thrombotic events post-splenectomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fatigue and pallor. A complete blood count reveals a haemoglobin level of 100 g/L. A blood film shows erythrocytes with a lack of central pallor, and the mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is reported as 38 g/dL. Which of the following laboratory findings would you expect to find in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Laboratory features of Hereditary Spherocytosis

Blood Film

  • Erythrocyte morphology in HS is inconsistent, often showing spherocytes lacking central pallor.
  • Patients with AE1/ BAND3 defects may exhibit "pincered" or mushroom-shaped red cells.

Erythrocyte Indices
  • Mild to moderate anemia (Hb - 90–120 g/L).
  • Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is elevated (>36 g/dL) due to cellular dehydration in about half of the patients.
  • Increased red cell distribution width.
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is decreased in severe cases.

Markers of Hemolysis
  • Laboratory features include reticulocytosis (Option D), elevated lactate dehydrogenase (Option B), increased urinary and fecal urobilinogen, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and decreased serum haptoglobin.
  • Direct Coombs Test - Negative (Option A)

Erythrocyte Fragility Tests
  • Spherocytes are osmotically fragile due to decreased surface area relative to volume.
  • The osmotic fragility test measures red cell lysis in hypotonic sodium chloride solutions; spherocytes burst at higher concentrations than normal cells.
  • Other tests, such as glycerol lysis tests, have poor sensitivity.

Eosin 5′-Maleimide (EMA) Flow Cytometry Test
  • EMA is a fluorescent dye that binds to specific transmembrane proteins (AE1, Rh protein, Rh glycoprotein, CD47).
  • HS patients exhibit decreased fluorescence compared to controls.

Advanced Diagnostic Methods

Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE):

  • SDS-PAGE identifies defective membrane proteins by separating and analyzing their quantities.

Molecular Diagnostics:

  • Identify genetic mutations associated with HS, including SPTA1, SPTB, ANK1, SLC4A1, and EPB42.
  • These methods are advanced and often used when other diagnostic tests do not provide a clear result.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with pallor, jaundice, and a history of recurrent episodes of hemolytic anemia requiring blood transfusions. He is diagnosed with hereditary spherocytosis (HS). His parents are concerned about the repeated need for transfusions and ask about definitive treatment options. What would be the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management of Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)

Splenectomy as Primary Treatment (Option C)
  • Splenectomy significantly improves anemia by prolonging red cell survival, reducing the need for transfusions, and preventing iron overload and related organ damage.
  • Post splenectomy: Spherocytosis and altered osmotic fragility persist, but reticulocyte counts and erythrocyte lifespan normalize.

Blood Film Changes Post-Splenectomy
  • Features like Howell-Jolly bodies, acanthocytes, target cells, cabot ring and Pappenheimer bodies appear after splenectomy.

 

Indications for Splenectomy
  • Recommended for patients with severe, transfusion-dependent anemia, growth failure, skeletal changes, leg ulcers, or extramedullary hematopoietic tumours.

Timing of Splenectomy:

  • Should be delayed until age 5–9 if possible (Option B), or at least age 3, to reduce the risk of post-splenectomy sepsis while balancing the increased risk of gallstones in older children.

Laparoscopic Splenectomy
  • Preferred method, with benefits like less discomfort, quicker recovery, and shorter hospital stays. Combined laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy is an option for patients with symptomatic gallstones.

Partial Splenectomy
  • Used in infants or young children to alleviate anemia while preserving some splenic immune function. It reduces transfusion needs but may eventually require total splenectomy in about half of patients.

Pre- and Post-Splenectomy Care
  • Vaccination: Patients should receive vaccines against pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and meningococcus before surgery.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Use of prophylactic antibiotics post-splenectomy is controversial but recommended by some for at least 5 years or even lifelong.
  • Folic Acid: Continued supplementation (1 mg/day) is recommended to prevent folate deficiency.
